service to Manila,

There we had a lunch,

arts of Philippine cooks with
those of

There were about seventy-five people
in the
party,
all
men,
and they certainly pulled right up to

and
went
to work like harvest hands on a Kansas
farm.
By

very good.
also had roast pig,
which was delicious.
And the best ham
ever eaten,
only had a small piece.
That was the
first line of defence which
the Lopez boys had
placed against
onslaught of the guest shocktroops, and the ham was taken
the very first rush.
also had corn
which was fairly good, but like the depression, very
on the cob tough.
roasted,
We got back
to town about three o'clock, and
went to
Fernando Lopez's house,
and later into a business
talk with the
two Lopez boys and their brother-in-law, Dr. Santos, and their
operations manager, one Lee Smith, who also
serves as pilot.
our business
about six-thirty, we went to
Smith's house for cocktails.
January; his wife,
rather first fiance
way from Atlanta, Georgia, to marry him about two months
to a party at the Lido restaurant, also owned
the Lopez
They had a fairly
orchestra, and we
had an exceptionally fine dinner with champagne, if you please.
The party broke up
Grooch
and I stayed at the home of Mr.
and Mrs. Fernando
Lopez.
We each
had a room.
The beds do
not have box or any
other kind
springs,
and no mattress--just a sort of cane,
like the seat
cane chair.
I have slept more comfortably.
I had a mosquito
netting around my bed (the houses have no
screens) and
the mosquitos
could not get at me,
them cruising around.
Their hum was occasionally drowned
out by
the squeek
of one of the many small lizards which are a
part of every well
run Philippine household.
The lizards are
little fellows, only about six inches long.
They live on flies
and mosquitos,
as far as 1 can see, there's no reason for
any poor little lizard to starve.
This morning,
we rose at five a.m.,
which was no hardship
for me,
in fact,
was glad to get up,
and had breakfast on
Lopez boats.
Then we took off for Zamboanga,
about two hundred sixty-five miles south of Monita, flying
almost due south
Irom 110110.
we got to Zamboanga at about
thirty and landed just for a few minutes.
to look over the harbor
facilities which we
were told, and
now know are not satisfactory for sea plane
landings.
found a place, however,
which should be o.K.
in any kind of weather, altho ten miles from the town.

Crater Lake is very

It is now

at Cavite, we found that Mr. Dodge,
